title: Trump Delays TikTok Ban Amid Claims of Election Benefit; White House Joins App
snippets: The new account comes as Trump has three times delayed implementing a 'sell or ban' law for the Chinese-owned app.
The popular China-based video sharing app has been facing a US ban over security concerns, although President Donald Trump has continued to extend the deadline.

US president was concerned over app’s Chinese ownership, but has softened after believing it won him 2024 election

The White House launched an official TikTok account on Tuesday, as Donald Trump continues to permit the Chinese-owned platform to operate in the US despite a law requiring its

While it was President Joe Biden who signed the law that would force  ByteDance to sell its stake in TikTok or face a ban, it’s his successor, Donald Trump, who has yet to fulfill his promise of arranging a deal to keep TikTok running, legally, in the United States. The current deadline for a deal [
titles: Trump’s White House takes to TikTok as deadline looms to ban platform
US: White House launches official TikTok account

The White House just joined TikTok
summary: Despite security concerns over its Chinese ownership, TikTok continues to operate in the U.S. after President Donald Trump delayed implementing a law signed by his predecessor, Joe Biden, which mandates ByteDance to sell its stake in TikTok or face a ban. Trump, who has postponed the decision three times, has softened his stance towards the app, believing it contributed to his 2024 election success. Meanwhile, the White House has launched an official TikTok account, indicating a further shift in the administration's approach to the platform.

title: Salah Wins PFA Player of the Year for Record Third Time; Caldentey Honored
snippets: Liverpool winger Mohamed Salah says it is "something I'll never forget and take for granted" after becoming the first player to receive three PFA Player of the Year awards.
The Liverpool star is the first three-time winner of the annual award, given to the best player in English football.
Mohamed Salah has been named as the winner of the PFA Players’ Player of the Year for the 2024/25 season.The Liverpool winger has been recognised with English football’s greatest individual honour...

• Liverpool forward wins honour for the third time

  • Caldentey award follows stellar season for Arsenal

Liverpool’s Mohamed Salah and Arsenal’s Mariona Caldentey have won the 2025 awards for the Professional Footballers’ Association players’ player of the year.<
Liverpool star Mohamed Salah has won a record third PFA Men's Player of the Year award, with Arsenal's Mariona Caldentey collecting the women's accolade.

summary: Liverpool's Mohamed Salah won the Professional Footballers' Association men's Player of the Year award for a record third time. Aston Villa's Morgan Rogers was named young player of the year. On the women's side, Arsenal's Mariona Caldentey received the Player of the Year award, with teammate Olivia Smith securing the young player award. These accolades follow exceptional seasons for both Salah and Caldentey with their respective clubs.

title: Air Canada Ends Strike with Tentative Deal, Flights to Resume Tuesday
snippets: The flight attendants' union said a new agreement guarantees members will be paid for work performed while planes are on the ground, resolving one of the major issues that drove the strike.

Strike over wages and ground work has cancelled travel for 500,000 people worldwide

Air Canada flight attendants say they have reached a “tentative” deal with the airline to end a strike over wages and ground work that has cancelled travel for half a million people worldwide.

Roughly
Air Canada flights will resume Tuesday evening, it said. Details were sparse on the tentative deal between the company and its flight attendants union, CUPE.

Air Canada flights are back in the air after attendants and the airline reached a tentative agreement earlier Tuesday. The union representing Air Canada’s 10,000 flight attendants confirmed its members would return to work, ending a disruptive strike that grounded thousands of flights and stra
titles: Air Canada flights slowly resume after flight attendants agree to end their strike

summary: Air Canada and its flight attendants' union have reached a tentative agreement, ending a strike that began on Saturday over wages and unpaid ground work. The strike, which affected 500,000 travelers worldwide, led to the grounding of thousands of flights. The new deal ensures that flight attendants will be paid for work performed on the ground, addressing a key grievance. Flights are set to resume Tuesday evening, though specific details of the agreement remain undisclosed.

title: Julio César Chávez Jr. Deported to Mexico, Faces Crime Charges
snippets: Julio César Chávez Jr., 39, arrested days after his fight with Jake Paul, has been deported to Mexico, where he's wanted for alleged cartel ties, following his detention in the U.S. for allegedly overstaying his visa and lying on a green card application.
Chávez was deported to Mexico on charges of cartel involvement, including arms and drug trafficking
Julio César Chávez Jr., son of the legendary Mexican boxer, has been deported to Mexico, where authorities say he faces charges of organized crime affiliation and arms trafficking.

In Mexico, he faces charges related to organized crime, including arms and drug trafficking. This legal action follows shortly after his fight with Jake Paul.

title: Rory McIlroy Buys 1,100 Masters Flags to Celebrate Augusta Win
snippets: Rory McIlroy said he took all 1,100 pin flags from the Masters Shop after winning at Augusta National in April. "I've waited 17 years to sign that flag in the middle, and I will never complain about doing it."

titles: Rory: Took home 1,100 Masters flags after win

summary: After winning the Masters at Augusta National in April, Rory McIlroy acquired all 1,100 pin flags from the Masters Shop, expressing his deep appreciation for the victory. He highlighted the significance of the win by stating his eagerness to sign the flags, a task he views as a privilege rather than a burden, despite the large number. McIlroy's comments reflect his fulfillment and pride in achieving a long-awaited milestone in his golfing career.

title: Vienna Chosen to Host Eurovision 2026, Marks Third Time
snippets: Austria's capital will host the next European Song Contest, organizers have announced. Vienna last hosted the extravaganza in 2015 and 1967.

Final of 70th edition of competition to be held on 16 May at the Wiener Stadthalle, Austria’s largest indoor arena

Vienna has been chosen to host the Eurovision song contest 2026, the world’s biggest live televised music event, Austria’s public broadcaster announced, with the final set for
titles: Eurovision: Vienna to host European Song Contest 2026
Vienna announced as host city for Eurovision song contest 2026
summary: Vienna, Austria, has been selected to host the Eurovision Song Contest 2026, marking the city's third time hosting the event, following previous occasions in 2015 and 1967. The final of the competition's 70th edition will take place on May 16 at the Wiener Stadthalle, Austria's largest indoor arena. This announcement was made by Austria's public broadcaster, highlighting the city's readiness to host the world's biggest live televised music event once again.

title: July Inflation Rise Dims Hopes for Bank of England Rate Cut
snippets: Economists say figure casts doubt on prospect of further BoE rate cuts this year

  • Rail fares in England expected to rise by 5.8% next year
titles: UK inflation rises more than expected to 3.8% in July
UK inflation rises by more than expected to 3.8% amid higher food prices
summary: Economists believe the increase in the annual July rate, influenced by higher costs for fuel and air fares, casts doubt on the likelihood of the Bank of England reducing interest rates this year. Additionally, rail fares in England are projected to rise by 5.8% next year, further contributing to the economic outlook. This combination of factors suggests that interest rate cuts are less probable in the current year.

title: Nvidia Strikes Deal with U.S. to Sell AI Chips in China, Offers Govt 15% Share
snippets: Nvidia last week struck a deal with the U.S. government to resume selling products in China, in exchange for giving it a 15% cut of the sales.

Nvidia is apparently putting together a new AI chip meant for sale in China that's half as powerful as its flagship B300 Blackwell GPU. The new chip would be more powerful than the H20 GPUs the company is currently allowed to sell in the country.
titles: Nvidia says it's evaluating a 'variety of products' after report of new AI chip for China

As part of this deal, Nvidia is developing a new AI chip for the Chinese market, which will be half as powerful as its leading B300 Blackwell GPU but still surpasses the capabilities of the H20 GPUs currently permitted for sale in China.

title: NASA's Webb Telescope Discovers New Moon Around Uranus
snippets: The James Webb Space Telescope has discovered a new moon that is small and dim in orbit around Uranus. The discovery brings the planet's total to 29, and scientists say there are probably more to be found

Using NASA's James Webb Space Telescope, a team led by the Southwest Research Institute (SwRI) has identified a previously unknown moon orbiting Uranus, expanding the planet's known satellite family to 29. The detection was made during a Webb observation on Feb. 2, 2025.
titles: New moon discovered orbiting Uranus is its smallest one
Webb discovers a new moon orbiting Uranus
summary: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope, operated by a team from the Southwest Research Institute, discovered a new moon orbiting Uranus on February 2, 2025. This discovery increases Uranus's total number of known moons to 29. Scientists believe there may be more moons yet to be found around the planet.

title: "Ghost" Proteins Found in Long COVID Patients Offer New Insights
titles: Scientists Detect “Ghost” Proteins That Could Explain Long COVID
summary: Scientists have identified "ghost" proteins in the blood of long COVID patients, potentially offering insight into the condition's underlying mechanisms. These proteins, not typically present in healthy individuals, could explain the persistent and diverse symptoms experienced by long COVID sufferers. This discovery opens new avenues for understanding and treating long COVID, marking a significant step forward in the ongoing research into the condition's effects and causes.

title: Scientists Struggle to Grasp Historical Biodiversity Changes
snippets: Despite growing concern about biodiversity loss due to the ongoing biodiversity and climate crises, scientists have relatively little understanding of the pace and complexity of biodiversity change over the preceding millennia.
titles: Exploring long-term, complex biodiversity change in Scotland's landscapes
summary: Scientists are facing challenges in understanding the historical pace and complexity of biodiversity change despite concerns over current biodiversity and climate crises. This lack of knowledge hinders efforts to address the issue effectively.

title: Genetic Mutation Found to Impair Lethal Cancers, May Lead to New Treatments
titles: This Tiny Genetic Glitch Is Crippling Some of the Deadliest Cancers
summary: Researchers have identified a small genetic mutation that significantly impairs some of the most lethal cancers. This discovery, highlighted in the study published on SciTechDaily, could pave the way for new treatments targeting these mutations, offering hope for improved cancer therapy outcomes.

title: 30-Year Study Links French Fries to Higher Diabetes Risk
titles: What a 30-Year Study Just Found About Your French Fries and Diabetes
summary: A 30-year study has found a link between the consumption of French fries and an increased risk of developing diabetes. The research, which tracked dietary habits and health outcomes over three decades, indicates that regular intake of French fries contributes to a higher likelihood of this condition. This study emphasizes the importance of dietary choices in the prevention and management of diabetes.

title: Investors Accuse Cenovus, Enbridge of Overstating Net Zero Efforts
snippets: The group Investors for Paris Compliance has accused Cenovus and Enbridge of overstating their efforts to reach net zero.
titles: Greenwashing Complaint Filed Against Canadian Fossil Fuel Companies
summary: Investors for Paris Compliance accused Cenovus and Enbridge of overstating their net zero efforts. The group claims the companies' plans lack transparency and ambition. Cenovus and Enbridge have defended their commitments, stating they align with climate goals. The outcome of the accusations is pending further investigation and response from the companies.

title: Scientists Unravel Mystery of Blazar's Neutrino Emissions with VLBA Imaging
snippets: A mysterious blazar that baffled scientists for years has been unraveled. VLBA imaging revealed a toroidal magnetic field powering a jet aimed at Earth, explaining how it can unleash neutrinos and gamma rays despite its sluggish appearance.
titles: Astronomers discover a hidden engine inside space’s “Eye of Sauron”
summary: Scientists have solved the mystery of a blazar, previously puzzling due to its seemingly sluggish nature, by using VLBA imaging. They discovered a toroidal magnetic field is driving a jet directly at Earth, enabling the blazar to emit neutrinos and gamma rays. This finding clarifies how the blazar functions despite its deceptive appearance.

title: Deel scores a lawsuit win, but not against Rippling
snippets: While Deel is calling this a "Rippling-aligned" suit, it's not the lawsuit filed by Rippling involving an alleged corporate spy.
titles: Deel scores a lawsuit win, but not against Rippling

title: Top pediatricians buck RFK Jr.’s anti-vaccine meddling on COVID shot guidance
snippets: The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends children under age 2 get vaccinated.
titles: Top pediatricians buck RFK Jr.’s anti-vaccine meddling on COVID shot guidance
